reasoning: The critique targets a real load-bearing move in the position: the Jones-style claim that short-run complementarity can be escaped quickly via rapid “reconfiguration,” so compute bottlenecks won’t bind early. If that move fails, one important pillar of the anti-bottleneck case weakens, though several other independent counters in the position remain (e.g., experiment efficiency gains, non-frontier experimentation, multiple routes), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The critique’s refutation strength is moderate: it offers a plausible counter-model (adjustment itself requires compute-heavy experimentation) and correctly notes that adjustment costs/time-to-reconfigure would need explicit modeling; however it is largely speculative and doesn’t show that reconfiguration must be compute-bounded in practice, so it doesn’t strongly overturn the position. Most claims are framed conditionally and are plausible, with no clear technical errors, hence high correctness. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little to no fluff.
title: Reconfiguration to higher substitutability may itself be compute-bottlenecked
